qText: Ram was / senior to / Sam in college.
solution:
The adjectives inferior, superior, senior, junior, prior etc. take the preposition to, not than. E.g.
She always felt inferior to her younger sister.
This material is superior to that.

qText: It was him / who came / running / into the classroom.
solution:
Change, It was him into It was he
As complement of the Copulative verb is Nominative case.

qText: The capital of Yemen / is situating / 2190 meters above / the sea level.
The captain along with his team / are practicing very hard / for the / forth coming matches.
ans: The captain along with his team
solution:
Replace, are practicing very hard → is practicing very hard
Subject of the verb must agree in number with verb. Here subject of the verb is Captain which is singular so it must take singular verb.

qText: Supposing if / it rains / what shall / we do?
solution:
Delete 'if'
Supposing it rains what shall we do?

qText: Either Nemmu or Mennu / are in the wrong; / both can / certainly never be.
solution:
Change, are into is


When two or more than two subjects are joined by 'Either, or' 'Neither, nor', the verb agrees with the subject nearest to it.

qText: None of two girls / who were present / appeared to be inclined / to listen to sane advice.
solution:
Change, None into Neither


None is used in reference for more than two. In reference to two 'neither' is used.

qText: Everyone knows / that the leopard is / faster / of all animals.
solution:
Change, of all animals → than any other animal
In a comparative degree THAN is used. Also, the term of comparison must exclude the things compared by use of OTHER.

qText: I and my colleague / have carefully considered the important issues raised by / the report which you sent me and / we have decided to take the following action.
ans: have carefully considered the important issues rai
the report which you sent me and
we have decided to take the following
solution:
Change, I and my colleague → My colleague and I.


Error in order of pronouns.
Order of Pronoun
Second person(2) + third (3)+ first person(1) in normal sentences. RULE-231
You, he and I have finished the work. (Normal idea)
I, you and he are to blame. ( here Confession of guilt is expressed , it's a negative idea, hence order is 123).

qText: Even if / the teacher has completed the / course the students cannot pass / unless they study themself.
solution:
Change, Themself into Themselves
The plural form of 'THEMSELF' is themselves.

qText: Ramu is the elected leader / and also a person / who we all / can confide in.
The gambling stall / was a grand success / because almost everyone / tried their luck.
solution:
Substitute, their → his/her
EVERYONE is a singular subject and must, therefore, be followed by singular pronoun.

qText: Little water / that was left / in the bottle was not enough / to quench the thirst of two persons.
ans: in the bottle was not enough
to quench the thirst of two persons

qText: The father / as well as the sons were / mysteriously missing / from the house.
ans: as well as the sons were
correct: as well as the sons were
solution:
Change, were into was


When two subjects are joined by as well as the verb agrees with the first subject. Above in the question the firs subject is The Father which is a singular so we need to use first firm of the verb which is 'was' instead of 'were'.

qText: Every man, woman and child / is now aware / of the terrible consequences of / habit of smoking.
solution:
Change, habit → the habit

Since, habit here has been particularized, i.e, the habit of smoking.

qText: If you saw / the amount of Samosas / he consumed at breakfast this morning,/ you would understand why he is so over-weight.
ans: he consumed at breakfast this morning,
you would understand why he is so over-weight
solution:
Replace, amount → number.
Difference Between Number and Amount 
The confusion between amount and number is common but can be easily overcome. They are not interchangable - their use relates to countable and uncountable nouns.
Use of Amount
Use amount is with uncountable nouns and abstract nouns:
amount of time
amount of snow
amount of noise
amount of love (abstract noun)
amount of pride (abstract noun)
Use of Number
Use number with countable nouns (things that can be counted):
number of cars
number of chairs
number of houses
number of topics

qText: As our room was / upstairs, so we/ didn't hear him.
solution:
Change, upstairs, so we → upstairs, we.
When a sentence is started with 'as', then 'so' should not be used in the middle of the two clauses as a linker.

qText: There are / no conducted tours / for tourist to visit all the / important places.
ans: for tourist to visit all the
correct: for tourist to visit all the

qText: On Friday evening / Mamta and me / took a coach / for Patna and arrived at Amit's house.
ans: for Patna and arrived at Amit's house
solution:
Substitute, me → I


Objective form of pronoun should not be used for one functioning as subject.

qText: This girl / wrote an essay / so well that / her teacher was exceedingly pleased with her.
ans: her teacher was exceedingly pleased with her
solution:
Substitute, 'an' by 'the'.

The sentence lays emphasis on essay.

qText: Everyone of the students / has bought / his / identity card.
solution:
Change, everyone → each one


When the number is limited or is implied to be limited 'each one' will be better usage than 'everyone'.

qText: The doctor said / that patient / should not have wasted / before coming for help.
solution:
Change, patient → the patient

Since, there is emphasis on the word patient.

qText: In my youth / I used to / visit / Sharma's and Chawla's company.
solution:
Change, Sharma's → Sharma.

When two nouns are closely connected the apostrophe's is added only to second.

qText: As he stood / below the shower / the sharp jets of / ice cold water revived his spirit.
ans: ice cold water revived his spirit
correct: ice cold water revived his spirit
solution:
Change, spirit ==> spirits
Normally, Spirit is noun which means soul or non physical part of a man or person (Sometimes, it also used as an adjective.). In other hand, Often Spirits is a person's mood or attitude. So, in above given sentence, revival of the mood of a person is quite suitable. 
See these examples: 
1. The warm weather lifted everyone's spirits. 
2. He confessed in a spirit of self-respect.

qText: Many a person / have lost / their life / and all property in the riots.
ans: and all property in the riots
solution: Many a takes a singular noun, which is followed by a singular verb.

qText: I have / two sister-in-laws / whose husbands / are all well settled.
solution:
Change, sister-in-laws → sisters-in-law.
 Plural of such compound words is formed by adding 's' in the first constituent of the compound word.

qText: I told him / the story / in details / to make him understand it fully.
ans: to make him understand it fully.

qText: Cattles / were grazing / in the meadows / near our farm.
solution: Change, Cattles → Cattle.  CATTLE are one of those collective nouns which though singular in form are always used as plurals.

qText: Many a man / have / been working / under me.
solution: Change, HAVE → HAS, Verb → Singular form.  MANY A is always followed by a singular noun and singular verb.

qText: The cricket / is a / game of change.
Mr Alexgander / has purchased / new furnitures from Metro-Mall.
Last year / many people / died from cholera epidemic.
Both the / girls helped / one another.
Vijay is / very much / sorry about her misconduct.
solution:
Very is used without much before adjectives and adverbs in the positive degree.
Here, Sorry is an adjective which has been used in the sense of sad. So, Correct Sentence is,
Vijay is very sorry about her misconduct.

qText: She treated/ me as though / an old friend.
solution:
Change, me as though → me like. 
Do not use a noun phrase, immediately after as if and as though.

qText: I'll go with you / as long as/ I won't have to sing.
solution:
Change, I won't have to sing → I don't have to sing.  
'as long as' is usually followed by a clause in the present tense when the preceding clause is in the future tense.

qText: She'll pay you / as soon as she / receive the parcel.
solution:
Change, receive the parcel → receives the parcel.
'as long as' is usually followed by a clause in the present tense when the preceding clause is in the future tense.

qText: I don't have a car / and I don't want / one as well.
solution:
Change, one as well → one either .
In a negative clause use either and don't use "not too/ also/ as well ".

qText: Indian scientists are no way / inferior than / any other scientists in the world.
ans: any other scientists in the world
solution:
Change, inferior than → inferior to.
It is better to use inferior to.

qText: Belgium chocolate is considered / by many to be finer / than any others in the world.
ans: than any others in the world
correct: than any others in the world
solution: Change, than any others in the world → than any other in the world.

qText: My grandfather owns / fifty acre / of wet land.
Our history can be seen / as a long evolutionary dialectical development / in which there have been / a painstaking forgiving of rational and moral self.
ans: as a long evolutionary dialectical development
a painstaking forgiving of rational and moral self
solution: Change, in which there have been → in which there has been.

qText: Our knowledge of history does not come to / Our help and some times we / even fail to remember / who invented America.

Our help and some times we

qText: The Committee has made / significant changes in / the rules which / will help to banks.
solution:
Help is a transitive verb. So, it should have an object. Here, TO doesn't require as help is transitive.
Therefore, to should be replaced by The.
Correct Sentence:
The Committee has made significant changes in the rules which will help the banks.

qText: This Project which is funded / by the united nations / has helped over four / lakh Indians overcome poverty.
The number of tourists / is expected to rise / from seven to ten percent / in the next ten years.
solution:

solution:

qText: The education Council / is consisted of ten members / all of whom / are experienced men.

qText: The woman who / has been perpetually hesitating / which of the two books / she will read first will probably read none and will suffer.
ans: she will read first will probably read none and wi
correct: she will read first will probably read none and wi
solution:
Change, she will read first will probably read none and will suffer → she will read first will probably read neither and will suffer.

qText: Summons were / issued yesterday / by Sessions judge / against the suspected thief.
solution:

qText: Teaching in this school / would certainly improve / if it had less boys / in all the high classes.

qText: Because of the cricket tournament / organizational work hardly / I have had any / rest since one week.

qText: A property dealer was /shoot dead by four unidentified jacket clad men /while taking a morning walk /in a park.
ans: shoot dead by four unidentified jacket clad men
correct: shoot dead by four unidentified jacket clad men
solution:
The sentence is in the passive voice so the main verb should be in 3rd form of the verb. Thus, Shoot should be replaced by SHOT.

Correct Sentence:
A property dealer was shot dead by four unidentified jacket clad men while taking a morning walk in a park.

qText: The newer type of automatic machines/ wash/ the clothes faster.

Hence, "the new/ latest type of automatic machines"  will be correct usage.
